title: How to Strategically Retire in Your 60s
subtitle: A clear roadmap for those in their early 50s looking to secure a comfortable retirement.
content:
How to Strategically Retire in Your 60s

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. If any of this is helpful, check out my new podcast, Your Money Guide on the Side, by clicking the link in my bio.

1. Calculate Your Number

Start by calculating your retirement number. This means taking your annual spending and multiplying it by 20. For example, if you need $80,000 a year, you're aiming for $1.6 million.

2. Adjust for Taxes

Now multiply that number by 1.15. Why? Because the number you just came up with—what most financial advisors tell you is the magic number—is actually pre-tax. In retirement, you won't magically evade taxes, meaning you're now aiming for $1.84 million.

3. Prepare for the Unexpected

Next, multiply by another 1.15. Why? Because everybody has a plan until they get punched in the face. You'll get punched, and it's important to prepare for that reality.

4. Max Out Your 401k

Now max out your 401k. If you're over 50, you benefit from a catch-up contribution of $7,000 a year. That means $2.1 million isn’t as far out of reach as you might have imagined.

5. Conduct a Spending Audit

Finally, run a spending audit to cut future liabilities now. Redirect every dollar from this point forward to your future plan. This proactive approach will ensure you’re on track for a secure retirement.
